headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Sept. 4, 2019

headline: The Upside of Partisan Division
summary: With any luck, Trump and Pelosi can fail to strike an infrastructure deal.

headline: Pentagon Advances Plan to Shift $3.6 Billion in Military Funds to Border Wall
summary: The Trump administration is moving ahead with plans to divert $3.6 billion from military-construction projects to build or fortify portions of a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

headline: U.S. Sanctions Iran’s Space Agency After Failed Launch
summary: The State Department imposed sanctions against Iran’s space program following a failed attempt to launch a rocket last week, which the U.S. suspects was an effort to advance its ballistic missile program.

headline: United Auto Workers to Target GM First in Labor Negotiations
summary: The United Auto Workers said it would target General Motors first in negotiating a new labor contract, aiming to reach a deal with the Detroit auto maker that can be used to set the pattern for talks with Ford and Fiat Chrysler.

headline: British Lawmakers Upset Johnson’s Brexit Plan
summary: U.K. lawmakers delivered a blow to Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s Brexit strategy, prompting the British leader to call for a general election.

headline: Dollar Index Climbs to Two-Year High
summary: The dollar reached its strongest level in over two years as the gloomy outlook for global growth, rising U.S.-China trade tensions and political turmoil in Europe weighed on major currencies world-wide.

headline: North Carolina’s GOP-Drawn Map Is Struck Down
summary: A panel of state-court judges struck down North Carolina’s legislative districts, ruling that Republicans improperly gerrymandered state voting lines to provide an enduring political majority for the GOP.

headline: Trump Warns China Not to Stall Talks
summary: President Trump said he would redouble his pressure on China if he wins a second term, warning Beijing not to stall trade negotiations until after the 2020 U.S. election.

headline: Trump’s Manufacturing SOS
summary: Tariffs and trade uncertainty punish U.S. goods makers.

headline: More Trouble at the UAW
summary: A federal corruption probe of the union appears to be expanding.

headline: Here’s What’s Sure to Happen in 2020
summary: Whoever Trump faces, voter turnout and the economy will be decisive.

headline: A Scientific Roundup
summary: The EPA intervenes against California’s rogue cancer regulation.

headline: How Bad Can a Trade War Get?
summary: The Trump China policy has fixed no problem, but the recovery can survive it.

headline: ‘Without the Banya We Would Perish’ Review: Sweat Like a Russian
summary: “Either socialism will defeat the louse,” Lenin famously declared, “or the louse will defeat socialism.” The louse won.

headline: End the Media’s Campaign Privilege
summary: As journalism blurs into partisan politics, the rules governing the latter are becoming unjustifiable.

headline: Tyson Cuts Full-Year Profit Forecast
summary: Tyson Foods lowered its earnings forecast for the year, citing short-term challenges that have weighed on its bottom line, including commodity market volatility, food regulations and issues at some of its operations.

headline: Cutting Medical Costs Can Be a Bargain
summary: Don’t underestimate inexpensive, low-tech methods of keeping people healthy.

headline: Dave Chappelle Is Stuck in the ’80s
summary: He made a career pushing the envelope, but his material—including the N-word—is no longer edgy.

headline: Economics Is Dismal, but Is It Science?
summary: A discipline that loves to challenge common sense makes me suspicious of its confident predictions.

headline: China Finds It Can Live Without the U.S.
summary: Hawks in Washington speak of ‘decoupling.’ Xi Jinping is already busy doing that—his way.

headline: FedEx Comes Under Further Scrutiny in China
summary: FedEx faces another investigation in China, this time suspected of illegally shipping a parcel containing knives to Hong Kong, according to state media.

headline: What an ‘Adversity Score’ Misses
summary: Students discuss the role hardship should play in college admissions decisions.

headline: Amazon CTO Details Company’s Path to the Cloud Business
summary: The company’s dominance in cloud computing is the result of early struggles with its information-technology system as the e-commerce giant sought to expand beyond online book sales, a top executive said.

headline: AT&T Names Media Boss as CEO Heir Apparent
summary: AT&T promoted longtime executive John Stankey to a newly created No. 2 role, setting up the WarnerMedia boss as the likely successor to CEO Randall Stephenson.

headline: Bankrupt Loot Crate Gets Creditor Bid of More Than $30 Million
summary: The proposed deal with a Money Chest LLC affiliate will be subject to higher and better bids in a potential auction supervised by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del.

headline: Gun-Policy Talks Await Signal From Trump
summary: Gun legislation negotiations are ongoing ahead of Congress’s return from recess, but the president has yet to throw his weight behind any specific proposals.

headline: New Software Tool Helps Arrow Electronics CFO Cut Costs
summary: Arrow Electronics, which sells to small and medium-size industrial businesses around the globe, plans to cut $130 million in costs by the end of the year.

headline: ‘Father Is Surgeon,’ ‘1 Mil Pledge’: The Role of Money in USC Admissions
summary: Emails show the school explicitly weighed how much money applicants’ families could donate when determining whether to admit students.

headline: New York City Declares Measles Outbreak Over
summary: New York City’s measles outbreak is over, health officials said, as a public-health emergency order was lifted.

headline: Deere Sells 30-Year Corporate Bonds at Record Low Yields
summary: On a busy day for corporate bond issuance, Deere sold 30-year bonds at an initial yield of 2.877%. That broke the previous record of 3.197% that Walt Disney had set when it sold 30-year bonds in July 2016.

headline: New York Fed Lays Out Projections for Future of Fed Holdings
summary: The Federal Reserve’s balance sheet, which has recently stopped shrinking, may once again start growing later this year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said.

headline: Fed’s Rosengren: Economy Doing Fine Despite Risks to Outlook
summary: Boston Fed leader Eric Rosengren said the U.S. economy seems in a good-enough place to avoid the need for rate cuts, in comments that shrugged off bond-market pricing levels that suggest a downturn is looming.

headline: U.S. Stocks Fall Amid Trade Tensions, Weak Data
summary: U.S. stocks and bond yields slumped as fresh data showed that the manufacturing sector contracted in August, adding to worries about the global economy and impact of trade tensions between the U.S. and China.

headline: New York City Opens Office to Combat Hate-Crimes Increase
summary: A former executive of the Anti-Defamation League was named the director of a new office that will work to stem the surge in hate crimes in New York City.

headline: Bank Stocks Fall on Global Growth Worries
summary: The sector slumped Tuesday amid concerns over the outlook for the global economy.

headline: Companies Use Cyber Ranges to Practice Security Skills
summary: Companies and universities around the country are building cybersecurity training centers that simulate real-world networks and breaches to train staff and test theories about how to guard against and respond to attacks.

headline: ‘Norman F—ing Rockwell!’ by Lana Del Rey Review: The Magic and Mystery of Life
summary: Touching simplicity reigns on the star’s latest album, which moves through humor, anger, heartbreak and, occasionally, moments of peace.

headline: Bangladesh Cuts Mobile Access to Rohingya Refugees
summary: Bangladesh says it will end Rohingya refugees’ access to mobile-phone services to help curb criminal networks that use mobile phones to coordinate, but the move will further isolate the troubled community.

headline: ‘Gorham Silver: Designing Brilliance 1850-1970’ Review: All That Glitters
summary: An exhibition of more than 600 silver and mixed-metal wares reveals the artistry and innovation of the Rhode Island firm.

headline: Pope Orders Officials to Shrink Budget Deficit
summary: Pope Francis ordered top Vatican officials to close a widening budget deficit at the Holy See and stop poorly managed spending and investments from undermining the operations of the Catholic Church’s global headquarters.

headline: Trade Impasse Sends Oil Prices Lower
summary: Oil prices dropped Tuesday as concerns mounted over the China-U.S. trade impasse and as Hurricane Dorian rumbled along a path that should keep it from disrupting production in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: Pence Defends Stay at Trump Property in Ireland
summary: Vice President Mike Pence defended his two-night stay at President Trump’s golf resort on an official visit to Ireland, as critics question whether he is using public dollars to benefit the president.

headline: ER Visits Precede First-Time Entry Into New York Homeless Shelters, Study Shows
summary: A study of homelessness in New York City found the number of hospital visits—particularly to the emergency department—began to increase in the months leading up to shelter entry.

headline: Celebrity-Backed Matcha Chain Tries Putting Its Cool Into Cans
summary: Cha Cha Matcha, the green tea shop with fashion buzz, is betting on millennial love of canned drinks

headline: Plan to Close Rikers Island Jail Complex Gets Key Approval
summary: New York City’s planning commission voted Tuesday to allow a plan to build four new jails to move forward, clearing a hurdle to shuttering the jail complex on Rikers Island.

headline: Dorian Is Exposing an Insurance Gap in the Bahamas
summary: The vast majority of damage caused by Hurricane Dorian to the Bahamas and other Caribbean countries is unlikely to be covered by insurance, which could slow recovery in the region.

headline: Goldman’s Coder-in-Chief Ditches Wall Street for California Sunshine
summary: Martin Chavez is retiring from Goldman Sachs, where he was the face of a new breed of engineers ruling Wall Street and one of its most senior openly gay executives.

headline: Italy’s 5 Star Approves Coalition Government With Ex-Foes
summary: Italy’s antiestablishment 5 Star Movement voted to form a coalition government with its former center-left Democratic Party antagonists, clearing the last major hurdle to new leadership.

headline: Students Using Phones Too Much in Class? Blame Parents.
summary: Students, teachers and administrators say parents light up their kids’ phones throughout the school day with text messages.

headline: Why This Fall Is the Ideal Time to Visit Chicago
summary: Happy hour at a Frank Lloyd Wright house—and about 100 other reasons why architecture fans should plan a trip to Chicago before the end of the year.

headline: Psychedelic Drugs Draw Some Investor Attention—and Much Skepticism
summary: A fringe group of entrepreneurs and investors see the emerging practice of using psychedelic substances for mental-health treatment as a business opportunity. Traditional health-care investors aren’t so sure.

headline: Trump Administration Mulls Cutting Refugee Cap, Keeping Iraqi Program
summary: The Trump administration is weighing continuing a special refugee program for some Iraqis while further reducing the cap on other refugees allowed into the U.S., according to people familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: Urbanists Sometimes Forget Urban Residents
summary: My mother-in-law lived in Manhattan for over 100 of her 105 years, walking to a bus stop a few times a week. When she couldn’t do that anymore, she took a cab to her medical appointments and social outings. Her independence depended on the availability of automobiles.

headline: Mileage Deal Is a Step in the Right Direction
summary: At the very least, the deal between the states, Ford, Honda, Volkswagen and BMW is a step in the right direction to stabilize market signals, preserving our long-term investments in innovative technologies and protecting jobs.

headline: The Amazon Site: Hey, It’s A Real Jungle Out There
summary: “Amazon Has Ceded Control of Its Site” sheds light on a little-discussed area of trade policy: the competitive advantage overseas firms enjoy over American companies with regard to regulatory compliance.

headline: Price Rises Above Inflation Already Standard for Drugs
summary: In the past three years, more than half of all sales growth for the top 45-selling drugs was due to price increases.

headline: Is China’s ‘Social Credit’ Heading to Hong Kong?
summary: One can’t imagine a more toxic poison to Hong Kong’s free-market culture than the imposition of China’s “social credit.”

headline: Japan Should Consider the Larger Picture With Korea
summary: As for South Korea and Japan, any alliance between the two is on shaky ground because of the historic enmity between them.

headline: Another Recession Sign to Ignore at Your Peril
summary: A worrying signal from the ISM Manufacturing Survey follows an inversion of the yield curve, and it no longer makes sense to keep explaining such signs away.

headline: Overseas Investors Unload U.S. Real Estate
summary: A strong appetite among foreign investors for office buildings, apartments, malls and other real estate has in part fueled the long-running bull market in U.S. commercial property.

headline: Team USA’s Huge Sigh of Relief
summary: Turkey misses four free throws in the last 10 seconds, and the Americans escape with a win. It won’t be the last time they’re tested in the FIBA World Cup.

headline: Democratic Candidates Ramp Up for Renewed Campaign Push
summary: Democratic presidential candidates are ramping up for a post-Labor Day push to win the party’s nomination for the White House, with Iowa caucuses now just five months away and the race still wide open.

headline: A Cincinnati Neighborhood With a Presidential Past
summary: Mt. Adams is one of the oldest–and priciest–communities in the southwestern Ohio city.

headline: At Least 25 Dead in California Boat Fire
summary: Dozens of people are dead after a fire destroyed a diving boat in Southern California, an event likely to rank among the nation’s worst maritime tragedies in recent years.

headline: Startups Snuggle Up to New York’s Pampered Pets
summary: The NYC Pet Tech Meetup—a gathering of New Yorkers looking to combine their obsessions with pets and technology into business ventures—has nearly doubled over the past year to more than 1,350 members.

headline: A Light-Filled Home on the Ocean in Kauai
summary: The owners vacationed at this 1,851-square-foot oceanfront home in Hawaii until they were able to buy it in 2011. It is listed for $7.75 million.

headline: A High-Tech Sports Bar on Wheels for Justin Moore
summary: A look inside the souped-up bus the country star calls Razorback, a tribute to the University of Arkansas.

headline: Beijing Asserts Power to Declare Emergency to Quell Hong Kong Unrest
summary: China’s top office for Hong Kong affairs laid out specific measures for the city’s leader to address long-running protests. Earlier, the city’s leader, Carrie Lam, had insisted her government can deal with the unrest.

headline: Photos: The Bus Is Its Own Show
summary: Country star Justin Moore shows off his beloved Razorback tour bus from a stop in Louisville, Ky.

headline: Bank of Canada Expected to Stand Pat This Week
summary: Market watchers predict the Bank of Canada will keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged Wednesday and hint it is ready to lower it to offset the fallout from escalating global trade tensions and slowing world economic growth.

headline: Credit Unions Go On Bank Buying Spree
summary: Credit unions are buying small banks in record numbers, a trend that is prompting pushback from the banking industry.

headline: Why Boris Johnson Might Call an Election, and How He Could Get There
summary: The U.K. prime minister indicated this week he would seek a snap election if lawmakers vote to tie his hands on Brexit. The route to a nationwide vote must go through one of three ways.

headline: Stocks to Watch: Alphabet, H&R Block, Conn’s, and More
summary: Alphabet, H&R Block, and Alexion Pharmaceuticals are among Tuesday’s stocks to watch, following the holiday weekend.

headline: Health Care Roundup: Market Talk
summary: The latest Market Talks covering the Health Care sector

headline: Queer Eye’s Antoni Porowski on How He Collects Sneakers
summary: The Netflix show’s resident food and wine expert depends on a surprisingly non-food-related app: GOAT, for collecting rare sneakers.

headline: Trade-Secrets Case Seen as Warning to Silicon Valley
summary: A trade-secrets case involving a Google affiliate highlights how federal prosecutors are now willing to file criminal charges in matters that are traditionally regarded as civil noncompete disputes.

headline: Thinning Liquidity Adds to Headaches for Traders
summary: The problem of thinning liquidity is complicating the trading of assets from stocks and bonds to currencies and derivatives, potentially exaggerating big moves across markets.

headline: In Economics Profession, Hotel-Room Job Interviews Get Nixed
summary: The American Economic Association is implementing new rules forbidding universities and other employers from interviewing thousands of candidates in hotel rooms during the group’s annual conference.

headline: The Hottest New Baseball Coaches Are Over 75
summary: Charlie Manuel, age 75, and Phil Regan, age 82, drew snickers when they were hired, but have proven that experience can be a valuable asset.

headline: Want to Save the Environment? Buy Oil Stocks
summary: Should green activists finance big oil corporations and anti-gun organizations lend money to arms manufacturers? As crazy as it sounds, financial theory provides a logically sound argument for why they ought to do just that.

headline: Miami Office Developers Step on the Gas
summary: Office development in Miami has reached its highest level since 2009 thanks in part to tenants relocating from high-tax states.

headline: Latest Oklahoma Export: Distressed Ukraine Loans
summary: After years of war and economic malaise, Ukraine is struggling under a mountain of bad loans. Now the crisis is creating a business opportunity for an Oklahoma family company.

headline: A Flawed Cap-and-Trade Plan for Water Could Come to U.S.
summary: An attempt in Australia to apply market discipline to the water supply has drawn criticism for failing to anticipate hoarding and theft. The approach is being considered in several western U.S. states.

headline: Hong Kong Chief Carrie Lam Says She Never Tried to Resign
summary: Hong Kong’s embattled leader said she has never tendered her resignation to Beijing and is committed to leading the city out of its monthslong political crisis.

headline: No Turning Back the Clock in Chip Making
summary: A new battle has emerged in the chip-making industry, though this one is unlikely to alter the rather harsh realities of that business.

headline: Troubled Pot Industry Shows Its Pick-and-Shovel Trades
summary: Investment legend has it that the best money in the California gold rush was made selling picks and shovels. Fertilizer and real estate are equivalent bets on the volatile pot boom.

headline: Chinese Steel Slowdown Slams Iron-Ore Prices
summary: Iron-ore prices posted their biggest one-month fall in almost eight years as China’s huge steel engine cools and global shipments of the commodity rise.

headline: Hurricane Dorian Raises Question: Should There Be a Category 6?
summary: Hurricane Dorian is reviving a question that arises whenever the U.S. is threatened by the fiercest of hurricanes. “This comes up every year whenever we have a Category 5,” said Ryan Maue, a meteorologist.

headline: The End of Small-Town America, in the Heart of Seoul
summary: The closure of Yongsan—the U.S. military’s crumbling garrison in downtown Seoul—marks the end of an era for a slice of Americana. “I’m seeing the death of a hometown,” said John Nowell, a retired U.S. soldier who moved there in 1965.

headline: Yearslong Tax Dispute Could Cost Big Tech Companies Billions
summary: A long-running tax dispute is racking up a potentially hefty price tag of nearly $2 billion and counting for dozens of big U.S. companies.

headline: Van Eck, SolidX to Offer Limited Version of Bitcoin Exchange-Traded Fund
summary: Crypto enthusiasts have been trying without much success to get regulatory approval for funds to bring bitcoin to investors. Two firms plan to use a workaround.

headline: Lego’s Bid to Beat the Pack Results in Sharp Drop in Profit
summary: Lego reported a sharp drop in half-year profit as it plowed money into opening new stores, creating new products and making digital investments in a bid to stay ahead of fast-changing consumer behavior.

headline: U.S. Tells Afghanistan It Will Withdraw Some Troops Within 135 Days of Pact
summary: Chief U.S. diplomat overseeing talks with the Taliban shared details of the proposal with the Afghan government, as the insurgents bombed the capital.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: P&G Takes Tide to the Cleaners
summary: Procter & Gamble Co. started the Tide Cleaners chain a decade ago to help market more detergent—and now that experiment is the No. 2 player in a sector where mom-and-pop rivals are struggling.

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: Walmart to Stop Selling Ammunition for Assault-Style Weapons
summary: The nation’s largest retailer will stop selling ammunition for assault-style rifles and handguns, further restricting its gun policies after two deadly shootings in Walmart stores. The company said it has no plans to discontinue all gun sales.

headline: U.S. Factory Activity Shrinks for First Time in 3 Years
summary: The manufacturing sector shrank for the first time in three years last month, providing the latest sign that a global manufacturing pullback is weighing on the American economy.

headline: Huawei Accuses the U.S. of Cyberattacks and Staff Threats
summary: Huawei accused the U.S. of “using every tool at its disposal” to disrupt its business, including launching cyberattacks on its networks and instructing law enforcement to “menace” its employees.

headline: Transcript: Reporters Hear From Richmond Fed President Tom Barkin
summary: Richmond Fed President Tom Barkin discussed his outlook for the economy and interest rates in an environment of heightened policy uncertainty.

headline: Coco Gauff Is the Future. But It Still Looks Thin on the Men’s Side.
summary: It’s been 16 years since Andy Roddick won the U.S. Open. The U.S. men’s Grand Slam drought is likely to continue with no stars on the horizon.

headline: Streaming Services Draw New Subscribers With Old-Time Rock ’n’ Roll
summary: Older music is the biggest growth area in music streaming, as labels look to cash in on their catalogs and streaming services seek to broaden their subscriber bases to include people more interested in Led Zeppelin than in Billie Eilish.

headline: Schools Pushed for Tech in Every Classroom. Now Parents Are Pushing Back.
summary: Over the last decade, American schools embraced technology, spending millions of dollars on devices and programs; some parents question how much it’s helping.

headline: America’s Stormy Affair With Apple AirPods: Love ’Em and Lose ’Em
summary: For some, anxiety over losing the wireless earphones clouds the liberating, wire-free experience. For others, product loyalty has prompted heroic rescues of earbuds that have fallen into storm drains and on subway tracks.

headline: Do You Remember? The Message in Earth, Wind & Fire’s ‘September’
summary: The 21st day has special significance in the 1978 hit inspired by the group’s founder Maurice White. And that famous refrain is really just “ba-dee-ya.”

headline: Hurricane Dorian Death Toll at Five in Bahamas as Storm Heads Toward U.S.
summary: Hurricane Dorian hovered over the northwestern Bahamas, killing at least five people, wiping out thousands of homes, forcing many into a makeshift shelter and leaving an entire island without power. The powerful storm was expected to approach Florida late Tuesday.

headline: Low Oil Prices Slam Saudi Economy
summary: Subdued oil prices are punishing Saudi Arabia’s economy, threatening the kingdom’s foreign-investment push and curbing potential investor appetite for an Aramco IPO.
